section.title: Schedule objects for deletion
section.para: Scheduling an object for deletion is helpful for managing objects that you do not want to permanently store, such as log files, recurring full backups of a dataset, or documents or images that become outdated at a specified future time.
To schedule an object for deletion, include one of these headers with the &PUT; or &POST; request on the object:

listitem.para: A UNIX epoch timestamp, in integer form. For example, 1348691905 represents Wed, 26 Sept 2012 20:38:25 GMT. Specifies the time when you want the object to expire, no longer be served, and be deleted completely from the object store.
An integer value. Specifies the number of seconds from the time of the request to when you want to delete the object.
This header is converted to an X-Delete-At header that is set to the sum of the X-Delete-After value plus the current time, in seconds.

note.para: Use http://www.epochconverter.com/ to convert dates to and from epoch timestamps and for batch conversions.

section.para: Use the &POST; method to assign expiration headers to existing objects that you want to expire.

simplesect.title: Delete object at specified time request
simplesect.para: In this example, the X-Delete-At header is assigned a UNIX epoch timestamp in integer form for Mon, 11 Jun 2012 15:38:25 GMT.

simplesect.title: Delete object after specified interval request
simplesect.para: In this example, the X-Delete-After header is set to 864000 seconds. After this time, the object expires.

screen.computeroutput: PUT /<api version>/<account>/<container>/<object> HTTP/1.1 Host: storage.example.com X-Auth-Token: eaaafd18-0fed-4b3a-81b4-663c99ec1cbb Content-Type: image/jpeg X-Delete-After: 864000
